question_text.markdown:
In general, the property (magnitudes only) that shows an opposite trend in comparison to other properties across a period is:

(JEE Main, 02 Sep 2020)

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (4) Atomic radius**

Across a period: IE increases, EN increases, EGE magnitude increases. But atomic radius DECREASES across a period - opposite trend.

question_text.markdown:
Three elements X, Y and Z are in the 3rd period. The oxides of X, Y and Z, respectively, are basic, amphoteric and acidic. The correct order of the atomic numbers of X, Y and Z is:

(JEE Main, 02 Sep 2020)

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (2) X < Y < Z**

In Period 3, basic oxides (metals, low Z) < amphoteric (metalloids, mid Z) < acidic (non-metals, high Z). e.g. Na(11) < Al(13) < S(16).

question_text.markdown:
The five successive ionization enthalpies of an element are 800, 2427, 3658, 25024 and 32824 kJ mol$^{-1}$. The number of valence electrons in the element is:

(JEE Main, 03 Sep 2020)

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (3) 3 valence electrons**

Huge jump between IE3(3658) and IE4(25024 kJ/mol). The 4th electron is from noble gas core. So element has 3 valence electrons -> Group 13 (e.g. Al).

question_text.markdown:
The process that is NOT endothermic in nature is:

(JEE Main, 04 Sep 2020)

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (2) H(g) + e- -> H-(g)**

This is exothermic: H has EGE = -73 kJ/mol (energy released). Ar + e- (noble gas, endothermic); O- + e- -> O2- (second electron, always endothermic); Na -> Na+ + e- (ionization, always endothermic).

question_text.markdown:
The electron gain enthalpy (in kJ/mol) of fluorine, chlorine, bromine and iodine, respectively, are:

(JEE Main, 07 Jan 2020)

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (3) F=-333, Cl=-349, Br=-325, I=-296 kJ/mol**

Cl has the most negative EGE. F is anomalously less negative than Cl due to compact 2p orbitals. EGE decreases in magnitude: Cl > F > Br > I.

question_text.markdown:
Within each pair of elements F and Cl, S and Se, and Li and Na, respectively, the elements that release more energy upon an electron gain are:

(JEE Main, 07 Jan 2020)

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (2) Cl, S and Li**

More energy released = more negative EGE: Cl(-349) > F(-328); S(-200) > Se(-195); Li(-60) > Na(-53). So Cl, S, Li release more energy.

question_text.markdown:
The third ionization enthalpy is minimum for:

(JEE Main, 08 Jan 2020)

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (2) Fe**

Fe: [Ar]3d6 4s2. Fe2+ = [Ar]3d6. Removing 3rd electron from 3d6 (one paired electron in half-filled shell) is relatively easy. IE3(Fe) is minimum among these transition metals.

question_text.markdown:
The first ionization energy (in kJ/mol) of Na, Mg, Al and Si respectively are:

(JEE Main, 08 Jan 2020)

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (1) Na=496, Mg=737, Al=577, Si=786 kJ/mol**

Anomaly: Al(577) < Mg(737) because Al's 3p1 electron is easier to remove than Mg's 3s2. Order: Na < Al < Mg < Si.

question_text.markdown:
The increasing order of the atomic radii of the following elements is:

(a) C, (b) O, (c) F, (d) Cl, (e) Br

(JEE Main, 08 Jan 2020)

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (3) F < O < C < Cl < Br**

Atomic radii (pm): F(64) < O(66) < C(77) < Cl(99) < Br(114). Across Period 2: F < O < C. Down Group 17: Cl > F, Br > Cl.

question_text.markdown:
B has a smaller first ionization enthalpy than Be. The correct statements are:

(I) It is easier to remove 2p electron than 2s electron.
(II) 2p electron of B is more shielded from the nucleus by the inner core of electrons than the 2s electrons of Be.
(III) 2s electron has more penetration power than 2p electron.
(IV) Atomic radius of B is more than Be.

(JEE Main, 09 Jan 2020)

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (3) I, II and III**

I: 2p electron is higher energy, easier to remove. Correct. II: B's 2p is shielded by 1s2 2s2 inner electrons. Correct. III: 2s has greater penetration than 2p. Correct. IV: B(87 pm) < Be(112 pm). B is SMALLER. Incorrect.

question_text.markdown:
The size of the isoelectronic species Cl$^-$, Ar and Ca$^{2+}$ is affected by:

(JEE Main, 08 Apr 2019)

options.text: azimuthal quantum number of valence shell
electron-electron interaction in the outer orbitals
Principal quantum number of valence shell

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (1) Nuclear charge**

Cl-(Z=17), Ar(Z=18), Ca2+(Z=20) are isoelectronic (18 electrons). Only Z differs. Higher Z = smaller size: Cl- > Ar > Ca2+.

question_text.markdown:
The element having the greatest difference between its first and second ionization energies, is:

(JEE Main, 09 Apr 2019)

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (2) K**

K is Group 1. IE1(K)=419 kJ/mol (removes 4s1 easily). IE2(K)=3051 kJ/mol (removes from noble gas core [Ar]). The IE2-IE1 difference is enormous for K compared to Ca (Group 2) where both IE1 and IE2 are moderate.

question_text.markdown:
In comparison to boron, beryllium has:

(JEE Main, 12 Apr 2019)

options.text: greater nuclear charge and lesser first ionisation enthalpy
lesser nuclear charge and greater first ionisation enthalpy
lesser nuclear charge and lesser first ionisation enthalpy.
greater nuclear charge and greater first ionisation enthalpy.

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (2) lesser nuclear charge and greater first ionisation enthalpy**

Be(Z=4) < B(Z=5) in nuclear charge. IE1: Be(899) > B(800) kJ/mol. Be has stable filled 2s2, harder to remove than B's single 2p1 electron.

question_text.markdown:
In general, the properties that decrease and increase down a group in the periodic table, respectively, are:

(JEE Main, 09 Jan 2019)

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (2) Electronegativity decreases, Atomic radius increases**

Down a group: Electronegativity DECREASES (larger atoms, electrons farther from nucleus). Atomic radius INCREASES (more electron shells). This is the correct pair.

question_text.markdown:
Aluminium is usually found in +3 oxidation state. In contrast, thallium exists in +1 and +3 oxidation states. This is due to:

(JEE Main, 09 Jan 2019)

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (4) Inert pair effect**

Down Group 13, the 6s2 electrons in Tl become reluctant to participate in bonding due to relativistic effects (inert pair effect). The 6s2 pair behaves as inert, making +1 OS stable for Tl (losing only 6p1), while Al always shows +3.

question_text.markdown:
When the first electron gain enthalpy ($\Delta H_{eg}$) of oxygen is $-141$ kJ/mol, its second electron gain enthalpy is:

(JEE Main, 09 Jan 2019)

options.text: Almost the same as that of the first
Negative, but less negative than the first
A more negative value than the first

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (1) A positive value**

The second EGE of O (O- + e- -> O2-) is always positive (endothermic, ~+780 kJ/mol). Adding a second electron to an already negatively charged O- ion requires energy to overcome strong electron-electron repulsion.

question_text.markdown:
The correct order of the atomic radii of C, Cs, Al, and S is:

(JEE Main, 11 Jan 2019)

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (1) C < S < Al < Cs**

Atomic radii (pm): C(77) < S(104) < Al(143) < Cs(265). C is Period 2, S is Period 3, Al is Period 3 Group 13 (larger than S), Cs is Period 6 Group 1 (largest alkali metal).

question_text.markdown:
The correct option with respect to the Pauling electronegativity values of the elements is:

(JEE Main, 11 Jan 2019)

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (2) Ga < Ge**

Electronegativity (Pauling): Ga(1.81) < Ge(2.01). Correct - EN increases across a period. Others: Te(2.1) < Se(2.55) so Te > Se is wrong. Si(1.90) > Al(1.61) so Si < Al is wrong. P(2.19) < S(2.58) so P > S is wrong.

question_text.markdown:
The element that does not show catenation is:

(JEE Main, 12 Jan 2019)

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (4) Pb (Lead)**

Catenation ability: C >> Si > Ge > Sn >> Pb. Pb does NOT show catenation because Pb-Pb bonds are very weak (large atomic size, poor orbital overlap). Sn shows limited catenation but Pb essentially does not.

question_text.markdown:
For compound having the formula GaAlCl$_4$, the correct option from the following is:

(JEE Main, 11 Apr 2023)

options.text: Ga is coordinated with Cl in GaAlCl4
Ga is more electronegative than Al and is present as a cationic part of the salt GaAlCl4
Cl forms bond with both Al and Ga in GaAlCl4
Oxidation state of Ga in the salt GaAlCl4 is +3

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (4) Oxidation state of Ga is +3**

GaAlCl4 is ionic: [Ga]3+[AlCl4]-. Ga acts as cation with OS = +3. Al is coordinated with 4 Cl atoms forming tetrahedral [AlCl4]- anion. Ga(1.81 EN) > Al(1.61 EN), so Ga is more electronegative and acts as cation here.

question_text.markdown:
In which of the following pairs, electron gain enthalpies of constituent elements are nearly the same or identical?

(A) Rb and Cs
(B) Na and K
(C) Ar and Kr
(D) I and At

(JEE Main, 28 Jul 2022)

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (4) C & D only**

C (Ar and Kr): Both noble gases have nearly zero/positive EGE (~+35 to +40 kJ/mol). Very similar values.

D (I and At): I(-295) and At(-270) kJ/mol are close in value.

A (Rb and Cs) and B (Na and K) have more differing EGE values compared to C and D.

question_text.markdown:
The correct order of atomic radii is:

(JEE Main, 12 Jan 2019)

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (1) Ce > Eu > Ho > N**

Lanthanoid contraction: atomic radii decrease across the lanthanide series due to poor 4f shielding. Ce(Z=58) > Eu(Z=63) > Ho(Z=67) in atomic radius. N (Period 2 non-metal, ~75 pm) is much smaller than any lanthanide. So Ce > Eu > Ho > N.
